results.title: ‘Insecure’ Broke Ground by Embracing Imperfection
results.abstract: The show, which ends this season, depicted its characters as authentically flawed. “True representation is the ability to show your vulnerability,” said the co-creator and star Issa Rae.

multimedia.caption: “The goal was to elevate regular Black people and make us look as beautiful in our regularness as humanly possible,” Issa Rae said of “Insecure.”
multimedia.copyright: Natalia Mantini for The New York Times

results.title: Elizabeth Diller Is Retelling Edmund de Waal’s Story — and Her Own
results.abstract: Designing a show at the Jewish Museum in New York has illuminated corners of hidden history in her life, the architect says. “Edmund dug into his past. I didn’t. I couldn’t bear it.”

multimedia.caption: A miniature carving from Japan around 1880 of a hare in ivory and buffalo horn, signed Masatoshi. This figurine inspired the British author and artist Edmund de Waal’s best-selling family memoir, “The Hare With Amber Eyes,” the subject of a forthcoming show at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.

A miniature carving from Japan around 1880 of a hare in ivory and buffalo horn, signed Masatoshi. This figurine inspired the British author and artist Edmund de Waal’s best-selling family memoir, “The Hare With Amber Eyes,” the subject of a forthcoming show at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.

A miniature carving from Japan around 1880 of a hare in ivory and buffalo horn, signed Masatoshi. This figurine inspired the British author and artist Edmund de Waal’s best-selling family memoir, “The Hare With Amber Eyes,” the subject of a forthcoming show at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.

A miniature carving from Japan around 1880 of a hare in ivory and buffalo horn, signed Masatoshi. This figurine inspired the British author and artist Edmund de Waal’s best-selling family memoir, “The Hare With Amber Eyes,” the subject of a forthcoming show at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.

A miniature carving from Japan around 1880 of a hare in ivory and buffalo horn, signed Masatoshi. This figurine inspired the British author and artist Edmund de Waal’s best-selling family memoir, “The Hare With Amber Eyes,” the subject of a forthcoming show at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.

results.title: Dave Chappelle Isn’t Canceled. He Just Likes to Talk About It.
results.abstract: In Netflix’s “The Closer,” he returns to views about transgender people that drew anger in his last special. With his popularity partly built on courting outrage, it’s no surprise he’s doubling down.

multimedia.caption: Dave Chappelle in “The Closer.” In middle age, he acts less like a comic and more like a pundit.

results.title: Concert Halls Are Back. But Visa Backlogs Are Keeping Musicians Out.

results.title: A Blackface ‘Othello’ Shocks, and a Professor Steps Back From Class
results.abstract: Students objected after the composer Bright Sheng showed the 1965 film of Laurence Olivier’s “Othello” to his class at the University of Michigan.

multimedia.caption: The composer Bright Sheng stepped away from a class he teaches at the University of Michigan after students complained that he had shown a film of Laurence Olivier playing “Othello” in blackface.
multimedia.copyright: Nora Tam/South China Morning Post, via Getty Images

results.title: Haile Gerima Is Having a Hollywood Moment. It’s Left Him Conflicted.

results.title: The Velvet Underground Meets Its Match in Todd Haynes
results.abstract: In the director’s hands, music subjects are as much about their cultural moment as about their sound — a good description of the band led by Lou Reed.

results.title: John Grisham on Judges, Innocence and the Judgments He Ignores
results.abstract: The best-selling author, whose new book, “The Judge’s List,” is about a murderous member of the bench, talks about the Supreme Court, wrongful convictions and what it means to be “review-proof.”

multimedia.caption: “I don’t think I would have become a writer had I not been a lawyer,” John Grisham said. “I never dreamed of being a writer. It was not something I ever studied. I never took a course in creative writing.”
multimedia.copyright: Donald Johnson for The New York Times

results.title: Andrea Martin, R&B Songwriter, Dies at 49
results.abstract: She co-wrote hits for En Vogue, Toni Braxton and other artists in the 1990s and 2000s and was also a singer, releasing an album.

multimedia.caption: Andrea Martin was a talented R&B singer with a solo album, but she was also valued as a songwriter for other performers — including Monica and Toni Braxton. She performed at the 24th annual Ascap Rhythm and Soul Music Awards at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in 2011 in Beverly Hills, Calif.

results.title: Love’s Perils, Trauma’s Wounds: New Story Collections
results.abstract: “The Ruin of Everything,” “Hao” and “Variations on the Body” explore fraught relationships and the long shadow of war.

results.title: When the Au Pair Helps With the Care of the Children and the Sex Life of the Parents
results.abstract: T.L. Toma’s second novel, “Look at Us,” follows a wealthy couple who embark on a sexual misadventure with their au pair.

multimedia.caption: “Look at Us,” by T.L. Toma, is frank and unflinching about desire, sexual dysfunction and the gulfs that can separate even the most intimate of partners.

results.title: Late Night Isn’t Threatened by Trump’s Latest Stunt
results.abstract: This week, Donald Trump said Republicans should not be voting in the 2022 or 2024 elections. “Wow, he’s been out of office so long, he’s forgotten how threats work,” Seth Meyers said.
des_facet: The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “That’s right, Trump is urging Republicans not to vote in the midterm elections unless the ‘fraud of the 2020 elections’ is uncovered, but for some reason, the thought of only Democrats voting still isn’t reassuring to me,” Seth Meyers said.
